number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Based on what the game looked like, I figured I'd probably just play it, kill some time and move on. But it was so much more than that.It focuses on the stories of four main individuals during the first World War. Each person has their own story and connection to one another, which is built upon throughout the game. It takes you through their travels and actually also gives very interesting information about the current setting you are in (factual explanations of tactics, battles, real people, etc) if you'd like to look into it. The character development is done in such a way in tandem with the music and art style so that you get very involved with it. You can get a feel for how the characters think and act, and start to feel what they are feeling. You may laugh, get upset, feel victorious, and even burst into tears. You start to feel as if you were part of their adventure all along, and will definitely feel emotions related to what is going on.There are four chapters in total, with each one containing several puzzles and scenarios that you have to piece together and go through to keep going on. Personally, they were a perfect difficulty; not♥♥♥♥♥♥easy, but also not ridiculously hard. Along with this, there are about 100 artifacts / trinkets / antiques that you can find throughout the game as you go to different parts (it's not required, it's just there for a challenge and more interesting information if you'd like it).All in all, this game was definitely one to remember. It shows how war brings out the worst in us, but also sheds light on how it can make us all a little more human.10 / 10 for a truly beautiful game.And yes, it's okay to cry.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Valiant Hearts is a beautiful looking and brilliantly put together game!This is tossed around a lot with other 2d games but playing Valiant Hearts is like playing a graphic novel. However, I feel as though this is the first game to fully accomplish this idea. The reason is because others games have the look, but no story, Valiant Hearts accomplishes this idea by having both beautiful 2d art and a great story to follow. This game accomplishes more with story and emotions in the 6 hours I played of it than many movies I've seen.As far as gameplay is concerned, it's done very tastefully. The game has a very serious tone, even though it may not look that way, and the way the game is played is never over the top. It plays like a 2d adventure game, where one person will need something form you before you can get the object you need to press one. There are series of puzzles that you have to figure out to get these items but it always fits within the context of the setting! One example is at a point in the game, you need to get a clothing item from a soldier, but he won't leave it until the barracks showers are running. So as soon as you get the water running again, you can get this peice of clothing. There are also some action oriented parts with shooting middles and throwing dynamite, so those of you out there not wanting to play just a puzzle game, you should be satisfied. One of my favorite parts about the game are the car driving dodging scenes. You are driving and something is chasing you and all the shoots and characters are timed to classical music. Amazing!Keep in mind this is no Call of Duty, Shoot, Kill, Shoot, Kill kind of game. It's more about pacing and solving the problem at hand. Fully recommended!

Posted: December 25, 2014
												I expected something simple, as far as side-scrollers go. Another war story, with action and adventure and some shooty bits. IT was on sale at the time, so I expected to get just about enough out of what seemed like a simple title.How little did I know or realize just how much was packed into this game - I put about 6 or so hours into it, and while to some that may seem to short, I would be more than a little surprised if in that time span you do not find yourself wholly captured by the story being told.. There are no gunfights, no akimbo-slo-motion jumps wiping out entire german squads at a time. Instead you wade neck deep through death and destruction desperately trying to survive.That in and of itself - Desperation - bleeds through the game as you play through it. At any given time you feel as if there just isn't enugh time, enough space, to just survive another inch. Watching as your characters move through conflict after conflict surviving by the absolute skin of their teeth sets you on edge the entire time. And yet, at no point do you ever give up hope that they may yet survive through the end, reunited on a farm that somehow might stay untouched during all that destruction.The music is gorgeous and the gameplay is well designed around said music. Chase scenes play along to the cadence of falling bombs and symphony, and struggles are punctuated by soundtracks chosen just perfectly for whatever it is you are dealing with at any given moment. This wonderful blending of game and music leaves an indelible mark - I can still hear the trailing piano notes from the end of the game in my head, and with it the story that was told.It was once said that games are not art - and yet, this game has within it the potential to bring you to tears, to fill you with the same emotions the characters would feel in those very moments - fear, anger, frustration, pain, and relief. I would challenge any who see gaming as something without reason or without soul to play this and walk away feeling as if they have gained nothing.This is worth every penny, even at full retail price. I've enjoyed this more than games easily twice its sticker price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Ubisoft Montpelier have done something surprising with WW1 in this game -- they made it both a learning experience and a heartfelt story wrapped around a series of interesting challenges in one place. One of the most terrible periods in human history is treated with both respect for those that fought while telling its own story of bravery and heroism.The game is saturated with historical factoids about the "Great War" ranging from a brief look at how armies were organized to the muddy misery of trench warfare and the dietary staples of the common soldier out in the field. These are written in easily digestable form so you won't feel as if you're going to be quizzed at the end of the game and often don't pull any punches when it comes to revealing the horrors facing these soldiers day-in and day-out. You can read them at your own pace if you don't want to call them up while treating the wounded or dodging field artillery shells during play, too, and they also feature actual pictures to drawings of artifacts from the period.Story-wise, the game revolves around four different people, each of whom have had their lives turned upside down by the war. Karl, a young man of German descent, is forced to leave his farm and his wife in France when the country decides to deport all German citizens in anticipation of hostilities with Germany. His father-in-law, Emile, is drafted into the French army. Freddie is an American who has joined the French army and is on his own personal quest for revenge. And then there's Anna,  a veterinarian turned field doctor who is also on her own quest to find her father. And even though she isn't a character in the game, Karl's French wife, Marie, from whom he was taken from is also present in the game. All of them also share their experiences via diary entries that you can read at your leisure adding quite a bit to the atmosphere of how their lives all tie in together and the cameraderie that they share as friends and family.The only one that doesn't have his own diary is Walt, a medic doberman dog that eventually befriends the characters and helps the player solve various puzzles in the game from flipping levers to grabbing hard-to-get items. He's a great lifesaver pulling more than his fair share of work with the player's help. And yes, you can pet him, too.As for the actual game, it's a mix of puzzle solving and action sequences such as driving along to a choreographed obstacle course. The story bounces between the characters with puzzles centerd on their specific skills. Emile is great at digging and can tunnel his way on through to other areas when he can. Freddie can cut wire with his pliers and is generally a tough guy with a heart of gold. Anna is often called on to heal the injured by following along in a rhythm-based sequence. Also, don't let the cartoony graphics fool you -- the game doesn't sugar coat the horrors of war such as when Anna is asked to saw someone's arm off in a field hospital and you need to match the sequence to do it. Many of the puzzles often involve finding the right items to get something done, such as convincing soldiers to let you pass on through so that you can get inside a building and find another item that you need.The actual puzzle solving isn't quite as exciting as the story, though, since it can sometimes feel as if you're going through a laundry list of things that you know you need to do anyway, but the presentation and the emotions that the game wants to bring out of you during the course of the game make up for that in spades. The music also provides a great backdrop and most of the characters only speak in brief grunts and ahhs with a few short lines to emphasize certain things, but it all works. The first thing I thought of was that it was kidn of like Scribblenauts only with a few voiced lines.As for the actual length of the game, your mileage may vary, but it tooke me around 8 or so hours to get through. Once it's done, though, there's no reason to go back through unless you've missed a collectable somewhere or just want to experience the story again. Unfortunately, replaying a previous chapter will overwrite the only checkpoint the game uses to track your progress, so be careful about going back.A surprising take on WW1 that no one else has really tried and a genuinely intriguing game. If you're interested in the history, a good story, and don't mind solving a few puzzles along the way, Valiant Hearts manages to merge it all into a remarkable time. Just don't forget the tissues. You might need them.

I bought the game on sale and it was totally worth it (even after the problems starting the game) and I would definitely repurchase again. I recommend this game for anyone who is interested in history and wants to have a little game to play every once in a while.

												a game which brings to light one of the darkest chapters in history. content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												As a history buff, I greatly enjoyed this game. It's comic-style artwork captured a different look into one of the most destructive human conflicts in history...and makes it easy to understand the struggles and triumphs of a small group of ordinary people and a dog, fighting a territory war between aging empires.A list of the emotions you may feel throughout your experience, in the order that I experienced them:Happiness...calm...hope...worry...fear...sadness...terror...anger...rage...pessimism...hope...joy...satisfaction...fury...hope...panic...relief...grief...emptiness...and the cycle concludes with happiness again.WWI was, in the eyes of many...myself included, a pointless waste of life. A battle for outdated ideas using tactics and technology that made life a living hell.If you wish to educate yourself about this conflict through the use of puzzles, then I recommend this title. If you do give this title a chance, always remember those that died....those...Valient Hearts.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												Spoiler warningThe art and music are both good and create the right ambiant. The decision to have the game start bright and colourful but gradually get darker and more violent as the war progressed was also good.However the game has two main problems:1) Anna's mini-games are difficult and annoying. Button mashing section don't work well in a game that primarily features problem solving.2) While the memorability is good in the non-dramatic sections of this game they completely ruin the drama in other sections. When Karl is trying to escape the French Police and Anna is trying to save Karl it breaks the immersion when the player has to waste time looking for items that have no relevance to the story. It would have been better if in these parts the objects related more to the story.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Lovely artwork. Atmospheric music. Good story. The puzzles are logical and enjoyable, thematic and move the story along nicely. The gameplay varies, so you don't get tired of doing the same thing over and over. Puzzles, dodging bombs, car chase scenes (I loved these), hiding behind cover, digging, firing mortars. None of the game mechanics are ground breaking and the gameplay is not very challenging (although there is a veteran mode, which I didn't try). But, the story is enjoyable and the gameplay is integrated brilliantly, with the mechanics causing tension at the right times.Really, this is a game is all about the characters and their story. The main characters are nicely developed and the minor characters stand out too. I like dark stories and this game has some very dark moments, as well as light ones. At times, I wasn't sure how I felt about the sometimes comical treatment of such serious subject matter, but overall, I think they handled the subject matter well and it's clear that they wanted to teach players about this major event in human history, while telling a story and providing a fun adventure game.Time played: 8 hoursRating: 3.5 / 5Reminded me of: Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons & Tiny Thief

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												This game shows, that Ubisoft is capable of producing not only sequels of prequels of sequels, but can make something new. Valiant Hearts: The Great War presents us a story of a family and their friends separated by the World War I. I can't say this is refreshing storyline in the gaming industry, but plays on emotions and touches from time to time.I also have to admit, that the game looks great - it is not Far Cry 4 or any AAA production, but has its own, unique style. The same could be told about the sounds.Unfortunately, one of the main parts of the gameplay - solving rather easy riddles - is annoying sometimes. As I said - they are easy, but it happened to simply stuck on the puzzle. An example could be throwing a dynamite to a container of some kind, when you have to aim quickly and very precisely. This could be too difficult for the kids and the game could become frustrating for them. It also made me mad a couple of times, when I had to quit the game and then repeat the whole level again. Yes, there are checkpoints, but when you want to leave before the level ends, then you have to be ready for this.However, I've enjoyed every minute of this (sometimes frustrating) game. Valiant Hearts is a nice tribute to all the WW heroes. I strongly recommend it to all those of you having a child in your families. Playing VH could be a great lesson of history to the little ones and could be fun to both of you.

												This game is one of those rare gems that is really more of an interactive story. It is beautifully told and has its cheerful, fun and heart-wrenching moments.Its really worth playing, despite UPlay. While I am not a fan of UPlay, I also don't believe that all the reviews claiming that they aren't buying this game because it is on UPlay. I think it is far more likely that a crew of anti-DRM activists go to many games that use UPlay and claim they won't buy them because of it. The fact that this game still have Overwhelmingly Positive reviews despite the anti-UPlay crowd speak to how great it really is.UPlay honestly has no impact on the gameplay. I wish Ubisoft would relax their DRM, but I don't really care very much, because I don't steal games, have a stable internet connection, and don't give my game keys to my friends. I think most people are in the same position.Call me crazy.

												Valiant Hearts: Tissues Not IncludedValiant Hearts: The Great War is a game I've been wanting to play the moment I heard when it took place; you see, WWI is often forgotten or skipped over, partly because it didn't involve a great evil threatening the whole world, but it was just as important to the development of the world in the last century, being one of, if not the last honorable wars, whatever you may think that means, either way, WWI involved a lot of new technologies from weapons to vehicles, to chemicals. And so, it is here that our heroes are placed, stuck in a global conflict, but only concerned for those that matter to them - this is not your father's war game.Gameplay: 98/100 A+Valiant Hearts is a straight forward game when it comes to gameplay, essentially a puzzle platformer with simple controls that are easy to learn and are applied masterfully within the world. There are also other gameplay mechanics taken from other games, such as "Guitar Hero" style push this button here or there. There really isn't much complaint on this end of things seeing how the gameplay was kept so basic, there wasn't much that could be ruined if it had existed to begin with. Saying that Valiant Hearts has a really solid gameplay almost seems unfair as it doesn't really change or reinvent what has come before, but then again, why fix that which is not broken? Not every new generation needs a reinvention, sometimes you just have to tell a good story - more on that later.Audio: 98/100 A+The soundscape of Valiant Hearts is warming, from the half-gibberish, half-actual words of the characters while playing, the dialog in cut scenes, or the narrator, Valiant Hearts goes by almost like an interactive comic book on WWI history, and that's not to downplay the game at all. The explosions fit the era, the music of the time, noises and ambiances all add to paint a picture of the conflict which raged across Europe in the early 20th century, and while it isn't perfect, it is damn near close, giving major, AAA titles an embarrassing run for their money. Everything is recorded and placed in the game carefully, voices are convincing, and the dog makes me wish I had one.Visuals: 100/100 A+As I stated earlier, Valiant Hearts plays like an interactive comic book detailing a story taking place during WWI, which isn't far off of what the style is, heavy black lines, bright colors and visuals which pair up nicely with the audio, creates a nice aesthetic. In a way, it falls right in line with other games such as The Walking Dead and Borderlands as far as the look goes. But it's not just the style that causes the game to be so appealing, the character design are also a highlight, as the various character's eyes are hidden, there's a different set of emotions and ways of reading the emotions on the characters, yet it still delivers, short and stout men, nimble women, all of it creates a world that is fleshed out on its own, despite being based on actual events in the real world.Content: 98/100 A+In terms of the actual game, one could easily finish it within a single sitting, but the same can be said about Portal. The game's puzzles and boss fights aren't too difficult to figure out, nor do they break the flow of action and drama that the game balances on when switching between the interchanging paths the characters are intertwined in. But unlike other war games, Valiant Hearts does a similar thing as Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna), where there is a historical aspect to the game. As you play along, your journal is updated with information either about your characters or facts about WWI, from trench warfare, technological developments, or how certain battles occurred. It takes the whole factual gameplay to heart, where you can learn something on a topic not many people know about, just like in Never Alone.Story: 100/100 A+And now we arrive at the bulk of why people just seem to love this game - the story. As many of you may know, I'm a big fan of a well made, thought out story, I don't care that it has been told before, I'd pick a good story over an original one most days of the week, and just like with the gameplay, nothing is really being reinvented, but more reiterated, that a character's journey is just as important as the soundtrack or the graphics. Here, we focus on a handful of characters, some torn apart because of the war, a father being forced to fight for the Germans while his father-in-law is forced to fight with the French. That in itself is a tension which can go in so many directions and pulling on a lot of heart strings, but the layers are just added, very carefully, like a layered cake, so that the whole doesn't come crashing down in a colorful mess. Without wanting to spoil anything, Valiant Hearts knows how to get the player worked up, either on the politics of war, family, friendship, and other things, and that should be applauded.Design: 98/100 A+Simplicity is the key here. Controls are simple, ideas aren't very layered, everything is straightforward, and there's not one thing wrong with that. While the controls may seem a little sticky here and there or it may take a few repeats to figure out a puzzle, it is far from game breaking. One thing worth noting is that, despite being a war game set in a war torn Europe, you and your characters never actually shoot anyone. It's always a joy to see a game take a risk on something we as a community have become accustom to. It's not perfect, but it is miles above most. If I did have to gripe about something, it is the fact that this being an Ubisoft game, UPlay has to open on top of Steam, and that's more to do with a problem PC gaming has with multiple platforms, but sometimes you just have to deal with it.Performance: 100/100 A+Smooth like butter over a nice crumpet at brunch. What can I say? The simple design and graphics makes it an appealing game that is easy on just about anything post 2001. Verdict: 99/100 A+Valiant Hearts is a game about people set during an often overlooked conflict, it is a game about trials and challenges, loyalty and friendship, love and family, showing that all of these things are more important than any war. From the music, the artistic direction, the characters, and the story, everything lines up just fine leaving behind a solid and emotion driven experience. Hell, even the UPlay login didn't bother me that much after 3-4 times. It's just good. I don't know what else to say. Just play it.

												All the reviews here seem to be giving glowing reports about this game. I wish I could find out for myself. After looking online I find I am not alone in having problems launching this program. I have tried starting it from the desktop shortcut, no joy. I have tried starting it from my Steam account, no joy. I have tried starting it from my Uplay account, no joy either. In each case it gets to "Press any button to continue", which I do, and then the program dies. Is that why so many people say they were crying about this game? If I could ever get it to run I might be able to recommend it, but until then it gets a thumbs down.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Absolutely a must have game.  The game play mechanics are simple and the difficulty is equally so.  This will not be a challenge to most people.  That being said, the narrative is fantastic.  Although a relatively short game (5-8 hours) the quality of the plot is worth the $15 price tag.Additional: Before going into this game, I knew very little about World War I, the game expects that.  Valiant Hearts is built in a semi-educational way and has direct links to Wiki pages about the real historical events.  Furthermore, the levels and collectables within the game have facts that are interesting to read.  This is a great mechanic for encouraging natural learning.  I kid you not, I spent more time outside of the game pondering and looking up facts about Vauquois and Ypres (and other events/items) then I did playing the game.  My 8 hours of game play (as of today) does not reflect the true time I spent with this game.  If you are vaguely curious about the Great War, start here.  If you aren't, still play the game.  Brilliant.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Like many others I really wanted to like this game: there's nice music, pretty, cartoonish graphics, information about WWI...I mean what's not to like? Uhmm...the story maybe? This game tries too hard to make you cry, I mean really, really hard, like chopping onions in your face, pulling your fingernails hard and, call me stonehearted, but it fails miserably. It's a tale of four war heroes (victims ?) whose stories intertwine and use up all the cliches in the book from orphaned children to hurting puppies. But even without the cheesy storytelling there's also:- mediocre at best puzzles (with a lot of running to-and-fro because you need object A that exchanges for object B that you get for object C)- the underwhelming level design that basically has you do the same missions three times over with slightly different settings (if I suck at the fist race level, I'm probably not going to improve by the second one 2 hours from now where the sole difference is the colour of the sky)- little to no background on the characters so you don't really get to build a relationship before the game puts them in seemingly impossible situations. (I mean, how am I going to shed a tear for *insert character name here* if all I know about him is that he can walk, run and sometimes change his clothes?)- I'm not one to say no to the ocasional deus-ex-machina, but this game makes a religion out of the technique. You build suspense by getting above mentioned character in said impossible situation that you can't see a way out of. Poof! Out of the blue the skies clear, they're saved and all is well again. By the look of this, you'd be surprised how so many people mananged to die during the WW- if your OCD compels you to collect all the items, you're most likely going to have a bad time what with them being hidden behind bushes and walls (that you obviously can't see behind), and blending so well with the scenery you'll start thinking maybe the game's glitching since you can't pick up more stuff- it's not that I mind having to go through Uplay to launch the game (too much), but does it really have to take 4 minutes on the clock between it registering that I've launched the game and actually launching it?***On the whole, I'd just head for the Wikipaedia page, read up on the WWI and save the money. Or maybe I'd buy if for a kid who's into war and stuff and likes comics and is just starting out in the puzzle solving bussiness. Yeah, maybe I'll do that.

												So far I haven't played the whole game through but the parts I have played through so far has been amazing. The characters, the history and the gameplay makes this into being one of the most fun and enjoyable experience of all. I am a person who enjoys compelling story, gameplay and characters and I can say I found all that in this game. I can recommend this for those of you who enjoy a bit of a puzzle gameplay, its not hard or unforgivningly hard but rather just use your eyes and mind and you will advance without a problem. For those of us who love a great story I will recommend this game for you. Besides handling charaters background and history good the setting in The Great War (the war to end all wars) is absolutly splendid. I found myself encrossing in a lot of history from different country during the WW1 and I just can't help but wonder why I never found out about these facts during my school years. I would say for those of you interested in viewing WW1 in a different light you may want to give this game a chance. Overall I'm in enjoying this game immensily and I will continue to play this game as soon as I am given more time in the future.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Fun game! I was surprised about how this game has an educational undertone to it. I actually learned a lot about World War 1 that I didn't know. Didn't expect that. Pros Nice art styleGood storyActually learns you something about WW1Good soundtrack Cons ShortPuzzles weren't really all that challengingI liked how no words are used during actual gameplay (there's plenty of talking through narration and cutscenes, however your playable characters never actually speak during gameplay) and still every puzzle and assignment feels intuitive and fun. NPC's mumble some french or german, but not in a way that it makes sense. Through speech bubbles with simple images they communicate their message in a clear way, which I really liked. The puzzles weren't really complex (asides from 2 safe lock puzzles where you need to figure out the combinations), but I think that's also because the game isn't out there to challenge you, but to tell you a good story and learn you things about WW1. And I think it did a great job at that!

												So I know that a majority of the reviews are talking about how you will cry. And in all reality, you will. I know I did. But there's more to this game than tears and sadness. There are uplifting moments to mirror the ones that knock you down. Yet still there is more than that.Pros:-Visuals: This game is simply a joy to look at.-Music: Personally this game has one of my top 5 favorite music scores.-Story: Really captivating, I had a hard time not finishing in one play through.-History: I enjoyed the little snipets of history this game provides.Cons:-Freddie needed more of a resolution for me.If you think you might like the style of art in the game, think the music is good, or simply want to feel some emotions, I wouldn't hestitate to make a purchase. You won't have any regrets.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												This game is a masterpiece.Unlike most games on WW I, this game tells us a more human side of WW I. An old farmer concripted to fight a war he want no part of. A young man separated from his loved ones just because his nationality, a man seeking for vengeace, a young woman chasing for his kidnapped father and a medic dog that accompany them.The game follows battles fought at the western front. With historical background supplied to the player. There are a lot of emotional moment. Prepare a lot of tissue when playing this game, the story is very touching. In the game we can see that the developers don't like the millitary leadership of that time, represented by ridiculous extreme hyperbole characters.There is a lot of puzzles to solve in this game, the number of collectible items are also ridiculously many! The music is superherb! I can't get tired listening to it!.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												This game is amazingly good. Good Stuff:  The story is one of the best I have seen in a video game.  The game comes packed with a bunch of historical information (pictures, short articles, etc).   The music makes the game so much more emotional.  The puzzles have a wide variety of difficulty, and if you are stuck, you can choose to get hints. Bad Stuff:    Sometimes the acheivements don't sync, particularly the one where you get all the collectables. This is frustrating if you are trying to get all acheivements.   The game is on uplay, so you get steam cards, but you don't get steam acheivements. This is a bit annoying.  Some have mentioned bugginess, I didn't get any, but it did drop frame rate once or twice. Overall, I would recommend this game. I got it on steam sale for a couple of bucks, and I have put almost 10 hours into it, and still need to finish up some more acheivements. A good buy. Plus, the story might make you cry!

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Ok so here we have a Ubisoft game that makes you put up with all of the UPlay crap and even has a couple of bugs, it's also 2D and it's a WW1 game where you actually don't shoot anyone..... And it's a masterpiece. This game is stunning, the art work, the musical score and the historical signifigance is unrivalled in video games as a whole. This game makes you care for the characters at a deeper level than you ever have before. It's also impartial and doesn't portay the Germans as "bad guys" and makes you understad the helpnessness of the situation.Throughout the game you have a dog as your companion and just like real life you form a bond with him very quickly. This game also doesn't outstay its welcome, taking about 7 hours to complete. It left me breathless and I absolutely love it!I have 1 major gripe, in the sections where you dig you must have the contols set to W A S D instead of the arrows or you can't progress. That aside the game is brilliant.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Being the full, red blooded male that I am *rips off shirt, drinks entire bottle of scotch, punches Ivan Drago in the face*, I rarely go in for the side scroller or the puzzle game, let alone both. I honestly don't know why, but after playing Valiant Hearts: The Great War (or Unknown Soldiers: Memories of the Great War, for those of you who are French speakers) it may be a habit that changes.I have always been fascinated by military history, particularly that of the 20th century, so I suppose it was only a matter of time before the game and I were aquainted.My curiosity was first tickled by the thought of a World War I game that wasn't a giant geopolitical simulator. If you try to find a WWI PC game that is anything other than a geopolitical simulator, you are going to compile a very short list.I was also drawn to the stylisation of the game, despite worrying about whether or not this whimsically (and stunningly) drawn cartoon of a game was going to trivialise something as cataclysmic as the Great War. If anything however, I would say that Valiant Hearts is not only a very good game, but I would say it is almost important that it should be played. That's right. I said that about a video game. Deal with it.The game starts with the outbreak of the First World War, a family is torn apart by the impending conflict; a father joining the Germans, a Grandfather joining the French. After the tearful cutscene (oh, there are a LOT of those) you are placed in the shoes of the French Grandfather Emile, and begin your conscription into the French army. The whole experience is chock full of pomp and that whimsy stuff, everything is bursting with colour and gayety (the French even have their historically accurate bright red trousers!). After a few more cheerful scenes of tomfoolery and mischief, the French finally march into battle against the waiting Germans, the Grandfather Emile carrying the regimental standard as the French advace slowly on the German positions.From the minute the German fire the first shot, you are robbed of that sense of light hearted cheer, as a French officer's body it ripped to shreds by artillery fire. As you charge across the field, avoiding heavy fire, the battered and torn bodies of French soldiers pile up, the colours fade and are replaced by the horrors of war.It's here the traditional puzzle elements really start to kick in and it starts off at a pretty relaxed pace, streadily getting harder over time. The progression is done rather well, with puzzles starting out easily and eventually evolving into real stinkers (for me that is, being a puzzle novice). To break it up there are some skill elements added to the game and skill based levels too, giving this game a nice balance of puzzle and traditional sidescroller, despite being quite reliant on script.The in-game collectables are pretty nifty trinkets from the era, helping flesh out the history of the Great War and greatly compliment the diaries of the characters and the in game encyclopedia. It is fair to say a concerted effort was made to add educational elements to the game, maybe even for kids, which I really appreciate.The style of the game is very reminiscent of the French cartoon film "Belleville Rendez-vous" in term of it's athetics and how they are both largely devoid of any form of dialogue. For a game set in one of the bloodiest conflicts of human history, Valiant Hearts is almost completely free from blood and gore. One would think that this would rob from the experience of a game set in the Great War, but trust me, with the direction that has been taken, this does nothing of the sort. I'd go so far as to wager that this jovial little title does more to immerse, shock and horrify the player than most story driven games of a gory persuasion. This direction again, could be seen as an attempt to make Valiant Hearts more accessible to younger kids.The story and characters are just fantastic. Utterly sublime. The story is beautiful and tugs at the heartstrings from start to finish and is told wonderfully throughout the game. The characters are so endearing its stupid. Seriously, it makes me feel bad. Even in short playthroughs of this game I have felt more empathy for 2D cartoon drawings than I have for people I would call close personal friends! And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ it, if they don't have the cutest damn video game dog in history to help you on your quests. GAAAAAAAH!I haven't seen a better job of storytelling and character development done by any game in the past few years, which when you consider the characters mostly communicate in pictures or by grunting at each other is pretty bloody impressive. It's actually quite clever what has been acheived here. Valiant Hearts perfectly captures the feeling of euphoria felt by many across Europe at the start of World War I. Ordinary people on both sides were genuinely ecstatic that war had broken out and wanted nothing more than to see the other side beaten. Steets were filled with flag waiving crowds, marching bands and troops paraded like toy soldiers while brightly coloured, jongoistic propaganda and recruiting posters covered walls. It must have been difficult not to get caught up in the excitement, only for the reality of war to be more horrifying than anything anyone could have ever perceived. The world's first industrial total war - killing done on an industrial scale, which could not have been more different from the street parties and colourful posters calling for young men to give the enemy a bloody nose.Valiant Hearts DOES this to you. It gets you caught up in that slightly dizzy euphoria and then, without warning, throws you into that man made hell of artillery, trenches, machine guns, tunnels, barbed wire, mud and gas. What makes it so heartwrenching is that the whole world is this happy little comic book, so beautifully drawn, and it is torn apart in front of your eyes, with awful trials and terrible things done to the protagonists you have come to genuinely care about.It is for reasons like these that I believe it is important that people play Valiant Hearts. On the surface it's a reasonably enjoyable puzzler, but underneath that it is so much more. It's a story about finding good in times where humanity is at it's worst. It's a story about love, revenge, friendship, loyalty, courage and a doggy. Most important of all perhaps is that it gives people a taste of the feeling that permeated the world at that time and delivers a moderate wealth of historical facts and information to boot. This game was made with at least some intention of teaching people. If I had to teach young kids about the Great War, this would be my first tool to give to them.Sure the gameplay itself is fairly average, but Valiant Hearts is a fantastic creation, with this unique character, so much so it borders on art. I have never cried at the end of a video game and I still haven't, but I came bloody close with this beauty.Valiant Hearts; charming, enjoyable, whimsical, jovial, thoughtful, joyful, tearful, beautiful, loveable.
